name: Apple — Apple scab
symptoms: discolored or blackened patches on the skin of the apple, scabby or raised bumps on the skin of the apple, curled or distorted leaves, premature defoliation (falling off of leaves)
spread: spread through wind-blown spores
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties and pruning and destroying infected branches and leaves

name: Apple — Black rot
symptoms: dark, sunken cankers on the bark of the tree, yellowing and wilting of leaves, premature defoliation, black or brown lesions on the fruit that eventually cause it to rot
spread: spread through wind-blown spores
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties, avoiding wounding the tree, and removing and destroying infected fruit and branches

name: Apple — Cedar apple rust
symptoms: orange or yellow spots on the top side of leaves, orange or yellow spore horns on the underside of leaves, distortion or curling of leaves, premature defoliation
spread: spread through wind-blown spores
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties and removing and destroying infected leaves and galls

name: Cherry — Powdery mildew
symptoms: a powdery white or grayish fungal growth on the leaves and stems of the plant, distorted or stunted growth, premature defoliation
spread: spread through wind-blown spores or contaminated seeds
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties, avoiding overhead irrigation, and applying a sulfur-based fungicide

name: Corn — Cercospora leaf spot (Gray leaf spot)
symptoms: small, purple, gray or brown lesions on the leaves, yellowing or necrosis (death) of the tissue surrounding the lesions, premature defoliation
spread: spread through wind-blown spores or contaminated seeds
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties and applying a fungicide

name: Corn — Common Rust
symptoms: small, orange or brown pustules on the leaves and stalks of the plant, yellowing or necrosis of the tissue surrounding the pustules, premature defoliation
spread: spread through wind-blown spores or contaminated seeds
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties and applying a fungicide

name: Corn — Northern leaf blight
symptoms: long, narrow, tan or brown lesions on the leaves, yellowing or necrosis of the tissue surrounding the lesions, premature defoliation
spread: spread through wind-blown spores or contaminated seeds
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties and applying a fungicide

name: Grape — Black rot
symptoms: black or brown lesions on the fruit and stems of the plant, shriveling of the fruit, dying back of the shoots and leaves
spread: spread through wind-blown or water-carried spores contaminating the plant through wounds in the bark
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties, avoiding wounding the vine, and removing and destroying infected fruit and canes

name: Grape — Esca (Black measles)
symptoms: black or brown lesions on the fruit and stems of the plant, dying back of the shoots and leaves
spread: spread through wind-blown or water-carried spores contaminating the plant through wounds in the bark
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties and removing and destroying infected vines

name: Grape — Leaf blight (Isariopsis leaf spot)
symptoms: small, dark brown or black lesions on the leaves, yellowing or necrosis of the tissue surrounding the lesions, premature defoliation
spread: spread through wind-blown spores contaminating the plant through leaves
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties and applying a fungicide

name: Orange — Haunglongbing (Citrus greening)
symptoms: yellow mottling or chlorosis of the leaves, stunted or distorted growth, premature defoliation, small, bitter-tasting fruit
spread: spread through the Asian citrus psyllid, a small insect that feeds on the leaves and stems of citrus trees
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties and destroying infected trees

name: Peach — Bacterial spot
symptoms: small, dark brown or black raised lesions on the leaves and fruit, premature defoliation
spread: spread through rain splashing the bacteria onto the leaves and fruit of the tree
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties and applying a copper-based bactericide

name: Pepper bell — Bacterial spot
symptoms: small, dark brown or black raised lesions on the leaves and fruit, premature defoliation
spread: spread through rain splashing the bacteria onto the leaves and fruit of the pepper plants
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties and applying a copper-based bactericide

name: Potato — Early blight
symptoms: large, circular or irregularly shaped brown or black lesions on the leaves and stems of the plant, yellowing or necrosis of the tissue surrounding the lesions, premature defoliation
spread: spread through wind-blown spores or contaminated seeds
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties and applying a fungicide

name: Potato — Late blight
symptoms: large, circular or irregularly shaped brown or black lesions on the leaves and stems of the plant, yellowing or necrosis of the tissue surrounding the lesions, white or gray mold on the underside of the leaves, premature defoliation
spread: spread through wind-blown spores or contaminated seeds
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties and applying a fungicide

name: Squash — Powdery mildew
symptoms: a powdery white or grayish fungal growth on the leaves and stems of the plant, distorted or stunted growth, premature defoliation
spread: spread through wind-blown spores contaminating the plant through leaves and stems
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties, avoiding overhead irrigation, and applying a sulfur-based fungicide

name: Strawberry — Leaf scorch
symptoms: yellowing or browning of the edges of the leaves, necrosis or death of leaf tissue, premature defoliation
spread: spread through wind-blown spores contaminating the plant through leaves
prevention: may be prevented and treated by avoiding overhead irrigation and applying a sulfur-based fungicide

name: Tomato — Bacterial spot
symptoms: small, dark brown or black raised lesions on the leaves and fruit, premature defoliation
spread: spread through rain splashing the bacteria onto the leaves and fruit of the tomato plants
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties and applying a copper-based bactericide

name: Tomato — Early blight
symptoms: large, circular or irregularly shaped brown or black lesions on the leaves and stems of the plant, yellowing or necrosis of the tissue surrounding the lesions, premature defoliation
spread: spread through wind-blown spores or contaminated seeds
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties and applying a fungicide

name: Tomato — Late blight
symptoms: large, circular or irregularly shaped brown or black lesions on the leaves and stems of the plant, yellowing or necrosis of the tissue surrounding the lesions, white or gray mold on the underside of the leaves, premature defoliation
spread: spread through wind-blown spores or contaminated seeds
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties and applying a fungicide

name: Tomato — Leaf mold
symptoms: a gray or brown fungal growth on the leaves and stems of the plant, yellowing or necrosis of the tissue surrounding the fungal growth, premature defoliation
spread: spread through wind-blown spores contaminating the plant through leaves
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties and applying a fungicide

name: Tomato — Septoria leaf spot
symptoms: small, circular or irregularly shaped brown or black lesions on the leaves, yellowing or necrosis of the tissue surrounding the lesions, premature defoliation
spread: spread through wind-blown spores contaminating the plant through leaves
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties and applying a fungicide

name: Tomato — Spider mites
symptoms: yellowing or bronzing of the leaves, stippling or mottling of the leaves, premature defoliation
spread: spread by mites flowing through wind
prevention: may be prevented and treated by releasing predatory mites and applying a horticultural oil

name: Tomato — Target spot
symptoms: small, circular or angular brown or black lesions on the leaves, yellowing or necrosis of the tissue surrounding the lesions, premature defoliation
spread: spread through wind-blown spores contaminating the plant through leaves
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties and applying a fungicide

name: Tomato — Yellow leaf curl virus
symptoms: yellowing, curling, and upward rolling of the leaves, stunted or distorted growth, reduced fruit production
spread: spread through small insects that feeds on the leaves and stems of tomato plants
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties and destroying infected plants

name: Tomato — Mosaic virus
symptoms: mottling, mosaic patterns, or deformities on the leaves, stunted or distorted growth, reduced fruit production
spread: spread through small insects that feeds on the leaves and stems of tomato plants
prevention: may be prevented and treated by planting resistant varieties and destroying infected plants
